question_details.query: When managing pastureland for natural pest control, is it better to delay mowing/grazing or to use grazing instead of cutting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on delaying mowing/first grazing shows mixed or neutral effects on natural enemies and pests: one replicated, randomised, controlled study found fewer predatory spiders with delayed cutting; other UK studies found no change in insect predator numbers; a Swedish study found mixed effects between predator groups; pest insects were higher in late-cut plots in one UK/USA study and unchanged in another (ID: 727). Additional studies report that delaying mowing/grazing increased some natural enemy groups (greater abundance of some spiders and ground beetles) and more insect species/individuals visiting flowers in some cases, while other studies found no clear effect on some insects and spiders (ID: 131). Using grazing instead of cutting also shows mixed outcomes: effects on natural enemies varied by species/date with one study finding no effect; among five studies on pests/diseases, one found more pests, two found effects varied by pest group/date, and two found no effect; one study found no effect on disease when grazing was used in addition to cutting (ID: 885).
summary_statements: Evidence on delaying mowing or first grazing shows mixed or neutral effects on natural enemies and pests.
One replicated, randomised, controlled study found fewer predatory spiders with delayed cutting.
Other UK studies found no change in insect predator numbers when mowing was delayed.
A Swedish study found that delaying mowing or grazing had mixed effects between predator groups.
Pest insects were higher in late-cut plots in one UK/USA study.
In another study, pest insect numbers were unchanged in late-cut plots.
Additional studies report that delaying mowing or grazing increased some natural enemy groups, such as some spiders and ground beetles.
Delaying mowing or grazing led to more insect species and individuals visiting flowers in some cases.
Other studies found that delaying mowing or grazing had no clear effect on some insects and spiders.
Using grazing instead of cutting also shows mixed outcomes for natural pest control.
In one study, the effects of grazing instead of cutting on natural enemies varied by species and date.
Another study found that using grazing instead of cutting had no effect on natural enemies.
Among five studies on pests and diseases, one found more pests when grazing was used instead of cutting.
Among five studies on pests and diseases, two found that the effects of grazing instead of cutting varied by pest group and date.
Among five studies on pests and diseases, two found no effect from using grazing instead of cutting.
One study found no effect on disease when grazing was used in addition to cutting.

question_details.query: What are the overall effects of altering pesticide application strategies to benefit natural enemies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence indicates several pesticide strategy changes can increase natural enemies, though effects often vary by group, time and context. Spraying insecticides earlier in the season was associated with more natural enemies in one UK study [723]. Using threshold-based spraying increased natural enemy numbers in two of three years in a Finnish study, with effects lasting as little as three weeks [750]. Delaying herbicide applications increased natural enemies in two randomized, replicated, controlled trials, though benefits differed among enemy groups and were fewer early in the season [774]. Broad reductions in chemical inputs often benefited invertebrates, but multiple studies also reported mixed, minimal or no effects [139]; specifically for butterflies and moths, reduced or less frequent chemical inputs were frequently linked to higher richness and/or abundance, with some studies finding similar levels to conventional management [3897]. Incorporating parasitism rates into insecticide thresholds produced acceptable pest damage levels, but effects on natural enemy populations were not monitored [726]. Experimental conversions to organic farming often increased natural enemies in 8 of 12 studies, but several studies found no, inconsistent or negative effects, and responses varied by enemy group and over time [717].

question_details.query: When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, what is the comparative evidence for planting new hedges versus plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Plants that produce attractive chemicals: Four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya tested planting non-crop plants that emit chemicals attractive to natural enemies; three (including one replicated, randomised, controlled trial) found higher numbers of natural enemies or attraction in lab studies, one found no effect on parasitism when the plant used was not attractive in lab tests; all four studies found reduced pest populations or damage; one replicated, randomised, controlled study reported increased crop yield; crops studied included lettuce, orange, safflower and sorghum [724]. Hedges: One randomised, replicated, controlled study from China found no effect of hedges on spider numbers in crops; of two studies from France and China, one found more natural enemies in hedges than adjacent crops while one found effects varied by crop type, hedge species and year; two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from France and Kenya found natural enemy abundance in hedges depended on shrub/tree species and varied among enemy groups; one randomised, replicated, controlled study from Kenya on fallow plots found pest (nematode) effects varied between nematode groups; crops studied included barley, beans, maize and wheat [752].

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies of allelopathic plant residues incorporated into soil, crop growth was sometimes inhibited (two of three studies) [728]. Yield responses included negative or mixed effects when compared with weeded controls (three randomized, replicated, controlled studies), indicating that yields were sometimes reduced under this practice [728]. Additional drawbacks reported alongside crop performance outcomes included short-lived weed suppression (lasting only days to weeks after incorporation) [728] and mixed effects on pests [728].

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to control weeds on farmland without relying on herbicides?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Incorporate allelopathic plant remains into the soil: across six studies (randomised, replicated, controlled) from Asia, Europe and North America, three found reduced weed growth compared to weeded controls, two found reductions versus unweeded controls, effects were sometimes short-lived (days to weeks) and varied by residue type and timing, and yield effects were positive, negative or mixed depending on comparison [728].
- Grow cover crops/living mulches in arable fields: four replicated, randomized, controlled studies (Israel, Italy) found fewer weeds with cover crops than without in some or all comparisons; other studies found more weeds, inconsistent effects, or similar weed amounts; cover crops also altered weed communities or reduced weed species in some cases [1394].
- Grow competitive plants to suppress damaging weeds (e.g., clovers, fescues, ryegrass, other grasses, turnip): nine studies (including four replicated, randomised, controlled trials) found reduced weed weight or ground cover; five studies found reduced weed reproduction and/or survival, sometimes only in certain years or conditions [722].

question_details.query: To provide refuge for natural enemies, what is the comparative evidence for creating beetle banks versus leaving part of a crop unharvested?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for leaving part of the crop or pasture unharvested or uncut includes eight studies across Australia, Germany, Hungary, New Zealand, Switzerland and the USA: three studies (including one replicated, controlled trial) found increased abundance of predatory insects or spiders in partially uncut fields or pastures, and four studies (including three replicated, controlled trials) found more predators in the unharvested/unmown area itself; two studies (one replicated and controlled) found a higher predator-to-pest ratio in partially cut plots and one replicated, controlled study found the same in the uncut area; one replicated, controlled study reported increased predation and parasitism of pest eggs in unharvested strips; pest responses were mixed, with two studies (including one replicated, controlled) reporting decreases in pests in partially cut plots (one species-dependent), two studies (one replicated, one controlled) reporting increases in pests in partially cut plots, and two studies (including one replicated, controlled) finding more pests in uncut areas; crops studied were alfalfa and meadow pasture [725]. Evidence for creating beetle banks includes multiple studies and reviews from Canada, the UK and the USA: six studies (three replicated, controlled, two also randomised) examined predator numbers in adjacent crops, with a review finding increased predators in adjacent crops, one study finding time-varying effects, and another finding no effect; two studies recorded small or slow predator movements from banks to crops; one study found greater beetle activity in fields without improved pest predation; four studies and a review found more invertebrate predators on beetle banks than in surrounding crops, although one reported time-varying effects; eight studies (including two randomised, replicated, controlled trials and two reviews) comparing beetle banks with other refuge habitats found two reporting more natural enemies on beetle banks (one seasonally), one review reporting similar or higher numbers, and four studies reporting similar or lower numbers; a replicated, randomised study and a review found largest pest reductions nearest to or on beetle banks, and one review found fewer pests in fields with beetle banks than without; one replicated, randomised, controlled trial and a review indicated potential economic savings if beetle banks prevent pests reaching spray thresholds or causing about 5% yield loss; design evidence from two UK studies indicated certain grass species supported higher numbers of predatory invertebrates; crops studied included barley, field bean, maize, oats, pea, radish, rapeseed, soybean, wheat and pasture [729].

question_details.query: What are the potential economic outcomes of adopting organic farming or alley cropping systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Organic farming: Experimental studies reported mixed yield effects (one positive, one negative, one mixed, and three with no or inconsistent effects) and mixed profitability, with one study finding higher net profit only when price premiums were received (otherwise profit decreased), and another finding negative or no effect on profit [717]. Alley cropping: Studies reported similar or lower yields, lower production costs, but overall lower profit in alley-cropped plots [718].

question_details.query: Which interventions are most effective for increasing pest parasitism rates?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Excluding ants that protect pests was associated with greater parasitism of pests in one of two replicated, controlled studies (one also randomised), while the other study found increased parasitism at one site but no effect at another (886). 
- Leaving part of the crop or pasture unharvested or uncut increased predation and parasitism rates of pest eggs in unharvested strips in one replicated, controlled study (725). 
- Using mass-emergence devices to increase natural enemy populations led to higher parasitism at one urban site but no effect at another in a randomised, replicated, controlled study (775). 
- Alley cropping showed variable effects on parasitism between sites, dates, pest life stages, or alley widths in two of four studies, while two studies found no effect on parasitism (718). 
- Growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals that attract natural enemies resulted in no effect on parasitism in one study in which the plant was not attractive to natural enemies in lab tests (724). 
- Incorporating parasitism rates when setting thresholds for insecticide use resulted in acceptable levels of crop damage in one controlled study; effects on natural enemy populations, including parasitism rates, were not monitored (726).

question_details.query: For pasture management in the UK, what is the comparative evidence on natural enemy abundance when delaying mowing versus using grazing instead of cutting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the UK, delaying mowing or first grazing date showed no change in insect predator numbers in three studies [727]. In contrast, using grazing instead of cutting showed mixed effects on natural enemies in studies from Australia and the UK, with some species or groups affected on some dates but not others [885].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of manipulating field structure by adding linear features like hedges, beetle banks, or alley cropping?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for linear features shows mixed but often positive ecological effects, with variable pest and yield outcomes. Alley cropping: Across four replicated/controlled studies, effects on parasitism varied by site, date, pest stage or alley width, with two studies finding no effect; fungal infection effects were mixed and egg predation was lower in one study; natural enemies included more wasps and spiders but fewer ladybirds in one trial, with hedge tree types influencing some groups; pest numbers increased in two studies, decreased in one, and varied by group/year in another; crop damage increased in one study and showed no effect in another; weeds showed mixed responses; yields were lower in a USA study and similar or lower in a Philippines study; costs were lower but profits also lower in a USA study [718]. Hedges: Two studies (France, UK) found newly planted hedges had higher beetle/spider abundance, richness or diversity than crop fields or field margins, and vascular plant diversity was higher than in recently established grass margins; a review reported newly established hedges supported more ground beetles than older hedges; a literature review reported lower pest outbreaks with new hedges; arthropod diversity varied among seven hedge plant species; an unreplicated German study found 2/85 ground beetle species used new hedges as dispersal stepping stones and passive movers (e.g., snails) benefited most; local hawthorn provenance grew better and was more stock-proof than eight other provenances [538]. Additional hedge evidence: One RCT in China found no effect of hedges on spiders in crops; studies from France/China reported more natural enemies in hedges than adjacent crops or context-dependent effects by crop, hedge species and year; two RCTs (France, Kenya) found natural enemy abundance in hedges depended on shrub/tree species and varied among enemy groups; nematode responses to hedges in Kenya varied among groups; crops included barley, beans, maize and wheat [752]. Beetle banks: For adjacent crops, a review found predator increases, while individual studies showed time-dependent or no effects; two studies observed small/slow predator movements from banks to crops; greater beetle activity in fields did not improve predation in one study; on banks, four studies and a review found more invertebrate predators than in crops, though effects sometimes varied seasonally; compared with other refuge habitats, results ranged from more predators on banks (sometimes seasonally) to similar or lower numbers; pest reductions were greatest nearest banks or on banks in one RCT and a review, and a review found fewer pests in fields with banks; an RCT and a review indicated potential economic savings if banks prevent pests reaching spray thresholds or causing 5% yield loss; certain grass species supported higher predator numbers [729]. Beetle banks and Lepidoptera: compared to hedgerows, butterfly richness and adult abundance were lower on beetle banks, while beetle banks and agri-environment field margins had higher richness and abundance of micro-moths than conventionally managed margins; caterpillar abundance on beetle banks was similar to margins, crop fields and other edge habitats [3927]. Beetle banks and mammals: harvest mouse nest densities were higher on beetle banks than on field margins [2393]. Hedges and Lepidoptera: established hedgerows had higher butterfly and macro‑moth species richness than in‑field beetle banks, crops or pasture in three of four studies; butterfly/moth abundance was higher along hedgerows than beetle banks, grass margins without hedgerows, field interiors, or 5–10 m away from hedgerows in five of six studies; gorse, oak and blackthorn planted within hedgerows supported more arthropod species, including caterpillars, than commonly planted hawthorn; moths near hedgerows were more likely to fly parallel to them [3976].

question_details.query: What actions are available to a farmer growing perennial crops to enhance natural enemy populations on the ground versus in the tree canopy?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Ground-focused options: Allow natural regeneration of ground cover beneath perennial crops; studies reported increased natural enemies on the ground in some cases and mixed effects on pests and canopy-dwelling enemies [720]. Plant or maintain ground cover in orchards or vineyards; multiple studies found higher natural enemy numbers in some or all comparisons, with parasitism of leafhopper eggs sometimes higher, though pest and damage outcomes were inconsistent and mowing timing influenced enemy numbers [1395]. Create beetle banks; studies and reviews reported more predatory invertebrates on banks than in surrounding crops, predators sometimes increasing in adjacent crops, and the largest pest reductions closest to the banks [729]. Grow non-crop plants that produce chemicals that attract natural enemies; studies found higher natural enemy numbers and reduced pest populations, including in an orange system [724].

Tree canopy-focused options: Isolate colonies of beneficial ants; increased occupation of cashew trees by predatory ants, with lower pest damage and higher yields [773]. Exclude ants that protect pests (e.g., using glue or pesticide barriers); some studies found greater parasitism of pests when ants were excluded, variable effects on other natural enemies, several cases of reduced pest numbers, and effective reduction of ants in tree or vine canopies [886]. Additionally, comparisons of natural versus sown or bare ground covers found variable effects on natural enemies within fruit tree or vine canopies [720].

question_details.query: What are the overall effects of weed management strategies that rely on plant competition or chemical properties?
To attract natural enemies for pest control, what is the comparative evidence for using manufactured chemicals versus planting non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Planting non-crop plants that produce attractive chemicals: Four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya tested such plants; three (including one replicated, randomised, controlled trial) found higher numbers of natural enemies in plots with these plants, and one found the plant attracted natural enemies in lab studies; one study found no effect on parasitism where the plant was not attractive in lab tests; all four studies found decreases in pest populations or damage; one replicated, randomised, controlled study found increased crop yield; crops included lettuce, orange, safflower and sorghum (724). Manufactured attractive chemicals: Across a review and multiple studies from Africa, Asia, Australasia, Europe and North America, effects were mixed; parasitism increased in a review and two of five studies, while two studies found increases only for some chemicals, crops, sites or years, and one found no effect; one study showed faster pest location by parasites; one study found lower egg predation by natural predators; five of 13 studies found more natural enemies, while eight studies (including seven randomised, replicated, controlled trials) reported effects varied among enemy groups, sites or dates; four of 13 studies (including a meta-analysis) found increases for some but not all chemicals; dose–response findings were inconsistent across studies; pests were fewer in three of nine studies (one only at the egg stage), more in two studies and unchanged in four; crop damage was reduced by some chemicals in one study and unchanged in another; one study found higher wheat yields; crops included apple, banana, bean, broccoli, Chinese cabbage, cotton, cowpea, cranberry, grape, grapefruit, hop, maize, oilseed, orange, tomato, turnip and wheat (754). Related evidence on planting flower strips (non-crop plants): Three replicated studies found greater pest reduction or higher parasitism in fields/farms with planted flower strips; effects on crop damage and pest numbers were inconsistent across studies; several replicated/controlled studies found more natural enemies in fields with flower strips or within strips, and species attractiveness and flower diversity influenced responses (1400).

question_details.query: What are the documented effects on crop yield when altering the timing of agricultural practices like spraying or mowing for natural pest control?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Altering the timing of insecticide use produced mixed yield outcomes across four studies from Mozambique, the Philippines, the UK and the USA: two studies found mixed effects on yield, one found no effect when insecticides were applied early, and one reported higher yields when spraying at times of suspected crop susceptibility [723]. Using threshold-based timing for pesticide applications resulted in two of four randomised, replicated, controlled studies finding similar yields to conventional spraying, while two studies reported mixed effects depending on site, year, pest stage/type or control treatment [750].

question_details.query: What is the evidence from North America for using natural or ecological methods to control weeds?
What is the summary of evidence on the economic outcomes, such as profit and costs, of implementing natural pest control methods?
What are the observed effects of using chemical or plant-based attractants to enhance natural enemy populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Chemical attractants: Reviews and field studies report increased parasitism in some cases, with effects depending on the chemical, crop, site, or year; some studies found no effect, and one recorded reduced egg predation; one study observed faster host finding by parasitoids [754]. Across multiple trials, numbers of natural enemies sometimes increased, but responses varied among enemy groups, sites, dates, and chemicals; dose–response patterns were inconsistent across studies [754]. Pest outcomes were mixed: some studies found fewer pests (including effects limited to the egg stage), others found more pests, and several found no effect [754]. Crop damage was reduced with some chemicals but not others; one study found no effect; one study reported higher wheat yields [754]. Plant-based attractants (growing non-crop plants that emit attractive chemicals): In four studies, three found higher natural enemy numbers in plots with attractive plants, while one found no effect on parasitism and laboratory tests indicated the plant used was not attractive [724]. All four studies recorded decreased pest populations or damage in plots with attractive plants, and one replicated, randomised, controlled study reported increased crop yield [724].

question_details.query: When altering the timing of chemical applications for pest control, what are the comparative effects of delaying herbicide use versus changing insecticide timing?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Delaying herbicide use: Two randomised, replicated, controlled trials found more natural enemies when herbicide treatments were delayed, with benefits varying by natural enemy group and being fewer early in the season [774]. One randomised, replicated, controlled study found more weeds when herbicide treatments were delayed [774]. Two randomised, replicated, controlled studies reported mixed insect pest outcomes: more pests for some groups in one study, fewer pests in one experiment and for one crop variety in another, and lower crop damage in some varieties and years [774]. Yield effects were mixed: one randomised, replicated, controlled study found lower yields and one found no effect [774]. Crops studied were beet and oilseed [774]. Changing insecticide timing: One controlled study reported more natural enemies when insecticides were sprayed earlier rather than later in the growing season [723]. Of four studies, two found fewer pests or less disease damage when insecticides were applied early rather than late; effects on a disease-carrying pest varied with insecticide type; two studies found no effect on pests or damage [723]. Four studies measured yields: two found mixed effects, one found no effect, and one found higher yields when insecticides were applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility [723]. One controlled study found higher profits and similar costs when insecticides were only applied at times of suspected crop susceptibility [723]. Crops studied were aubergine, barley, maize, pear and stringbean [723].

question_details.query: What are the documented financial impacts, in terms of profit and costs, of implementing various natural pest control strategies?
What actions are available to control weeds specifically in pasture or grassland systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Available actions for weed control in pasture/grassland systems include: using mixed pastures rather than monocultures, which reduced weeds in two randomized, replicated trials in the USA (721); mowing or cutting semi-natural grasslands/pastures (339); implementing lenient grazing for long-term control of creeping thistle, alongside cutting and biological control via fungal pathogens or weevils to infect creeping thistle with systemic rust (123); applying herbicides, noting mixed results: a grass‑specific herbicide eliminated black grass with a December treatment and reduced grass diversity while increasing broadleaved plants in one study, high‑concentration herbicide killed less than half of broad‑leaved dock plants, and herbicides reduced cover of certain grasses including purple moor grass in some studies (123, 1643); selecting sheep breeds that preferentially graze target species, as Hebridean sheep grazed more purple moor grass than Swaledale sheep (123); and using mowing, weeding, or herbicide as part of grassland restoration or creation efforts (3943). Annual mowing also maintained the highest number of plant species in wood pasture, supporting mowing as a maintenance action (649).
